channel.name: Does an example exist for verifying with o1js the data availability proof on Celestia?

messages.content: As I understand, the [data availability proof](https://github.com/ashishbhintade/cntsc/blob/main/src/types/blob.ts#L16) on Celestia is a kind of Merkle Witness, and SHA256 is used for commitment calculations. Does any repo exist that verifies those proofs using o1js?

I've found a tutorial and solidity code
https://docs.celestia.org/developers/blobstream-proof-queries#full-example-of-proving-that-a-celestia-block-was-committed-to-by-blobstream-x-contract
https://github.com/celestiaorg/blobstream-contracts/blob/3a552d8f7bfbed1f3175933260e6e440915d2da4/src/lib/verifier/test/RollupInclusionProofs.t.sol

So one way it to try to port this code, but I've seen announcement by @madeleine | zkintern that Celestia is being integrated to Mina, so probably this work is already done?
https://discord.com/channels/484437221055922177/601171209287368715/1232319694304706590

They started work on it, mainly on integrating the BlobstreamX bridge. But that's far from ready afaik. Also, inclusion proofs on celestia seem pretty difficult to achieve imo, since SHA256 hashing is crazy expensive in kimchi currently (something in the realm of 4k constraints), and you'd have to hash 256? times to prove one DA inclusion
Thank you!

The proof for given data that API is giving is not big, but probably they do not include blocks proofs there
```
[
            {
              start: 7,
              end: 8,
              nodes: [
                "AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAQAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAArOoB2GZtxyL1Ff7rObsGwuL6aJDcNW6H67C68XaJG2SAkbeLm2ZQkUV",
                "AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAKzqAdhmbcci9QAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAArOoB2GZtxyL1KgD3Is7Fy/ooimRiH1FrZxfawk2ZyntC+oP9lCCrZjY",
                "AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAKzqAdhmbcci9QAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAArOoB2GZtxyL1DYk+noaDez4sYti1xW8ZohlsjQOL+tZGOsaWzE9+qct",
                "AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAIBAQ2Jnsa1lIYMAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAgEBDYmexrWUhg5gWJUfdwJSAg2fSXB8BmliTnucIK3a7JxBMZ5jKoNPX",
                "AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAI+HNrb/ncCAZaYAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAj4c2tv+dwIBlpmkya2VK54bMelNO6PfZkzcQR0u9MDvyo+sbygm18yZ+",
                "/////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////xhuXn3Vv1c/dvpNwOLQIVE2fT9wivOn6upUhLZPIzQk",
              ],
              is_max_namespace_ignored: true,
            },
],
```

iiuc celestia chooses the merkle tree height dynamically based on how many blobs a given block contains. And this difficult to build in a circuit context, as you always have to assume the maximum height
didn't find too many resources on that either tho

So it seems like for now the feasible option is to just use the oracle certifying the result of the API call verifying the proof.
@br0wnD3v is it possible to add it to the Doot? I can give all the API call details for testing it, I have Celestia light node running.
Solution would be to publish the data as events on the L1
it's tedious but possible

Hey @DFST Good evening :) I havent looked into celestia much but since you have already figured out the details, I have no problem pushing it on Doot, maybe I can use the Async circuits here as well and get you verifiable proofs too
Great, I will DM your details for testing

On the L1 will be published the root of the Merkle Tree using the proof proving that the Merkle Tree was updated in accordance with the rules, and I agree that events can be used, but you can put only the aggregate data in events, not all rollup transactions as there can be thousands of rollup tx and they will not fit into events.

The goal is to prove that data that is used to calculate the Merkle Tree root is available.

> you can put only the aggregate data in events
You can just split it up into multiple transactions and track some sort of commitment to check the completeness of your published data at the end. They obviously have to be multiple transactions, depending on your tx volume, it's gonna get expensive, etc pp. But currently it's the only trustless solution that's available. All other options you've mentioned are trusted
We are working on a Mina-specific DA layer that solves those issues tho

Great! Would love to see what you will do. Agree with you, maybe the solution is to put those many txs with events into Zeko that will keep the proof of state in Mina L1.
Is it possible to add events to non-zkApps txs? There are several time more usual payments txs that can be included into the L1 block than zkApp txs.

No, because Zeko is a L2 themselves, you have to look at what their DA mode is because you as a L3 will inherit that. And currently it is a DA-Committee with maybe 3 parties? I wouldn't frame that as trustless and we can (and should) definitely do better than that

> Is it possible to add events to non-zkApps txs
I think so - but it loses it's meaning because you can't assert the data's validity afterwards
How can I assert data validity with events in zkApp? As I understand, zkApp on-chain can see only actions, not events
I mean you do this like you would control the emitting of events in general. With the zkapps protocol
It would be best to increase throughput of events. We haven't found a good reasoning behind the hard-coded limit of 100 per tx.

You are right; they define Merkle Tree size dynamically. Quite hard to create a proof for it(
https://github.com/celestiaorg/go-square/blob/main/inclusion/commitment.go#L95

btw, @rpanic it is possible thanks to your work on verification keys sideloading. You can define Zkprograms for all Merkle Tree sizes, put verification keys hashes to the Merkle Tree, and then in the contract, verify
- proof by ZkProgram for the Merkle Tree of given size
- that sideloaded verification key is present in the Merkle Tree holding all verification keys
On Ethereum, it is possible to verify the Celestia data inclusion proof with blobstream. Can we verify the data there and move somehow the verification thru lambda bridge to Mina?
bridge is of the opposite way
used to be 16 fields! 😄
Yeah, the question is where did those numbers come from? Why can't it be like 10x or 100x more.
maybe @nholland94 can share more light into that

Hey everyone, Geometry is working on a pairing verifier in o1js that will be able to verify both blobstreamx and possibly also a state inclusion proof 

They are making good progress, the circuit exists. The verification will need to be split into 10-15 proofs though because of its size

Could the number of proofs for the state inclusion proofs be reduced in cases with a fixed Celestia blob size?

Celestia is dynamically calculating Merkle Tree heights, and for fixed size blob, the tree heights will be fixed too (although different for different sizes). It can be quite a low number (for example, for a blob containing one Field, it takes only one sha256 hash to go from blob data to commitment, i.e., Merkle Tree root for a blob).
So, the circuit size should be smaller for fixed-size blobs of 1, 10, or 100 Fields, and most zkApps will use fixed-size blobs.
The tree height depends on the number of blobs in a celestia block - something you can't influence or fix

It’s one level higher, the first calculation is on blob itself
https://github.com/celestiaorg/go-square/blob/main/inclusion/commitment.go#L19

So I was actually just talking about the pairing verification, which you would use to recursively verify blobstreamx.

For the state proof, there is no implementation directly in o1js right now. But should be easy-ish with the sha2 gadget?
